comments.commentBody:
I would expect the author to have gone into more detail in his book rather than in a short article.
He does not appear to have left anyone out either the left or the right in general terms.
We can all see the corruption that infests both parties easily enough. It is corruption and unethical conduct that lies at the root of these violations of Constitutional Rights, not any particular political stance beyond a willingness to violate the rights of others.
That is all it took for these things to happen.

The article on on the increasing reliance on government benefits by some of the very people that hate government is a companion piece to this column.  And you are so right Meredith! I am trying not to despair that our fellow Americans can continue to be duped in this way and wondering whether they indeed have been given kool-aid in the form of the Fox and talk radio daily repetition of the lies!  I only hope that the gop have gone so far over the edge that even the clueless masses have begun to wake up!

Why has the right wing taken over the gop, and pushed the dems rightward too? Our politics has a built in mechanism for this. They just appeal to the anti govt forces, by identifying govt with socialism, leading to communism, leading to loss of “freedom, leading to dictatorship. This is done using slogans appealing to the unconscious, by passing rational thinking. Once they convince millions of voters that govt is the problem, then the constantly propagandize against it. They build on previous rhetoric to go ever further out from common sense. They bring moderate democrats into the fold by making them fear criticism of objections as left wing. The gop convinces voters to vote for the removal of the very thing that protects them from economic predators. Then they watch as the wealth flows upward, and millions of working middle class people are left without jobs, savings, health insurance, education and retirement. That a modern democracy could go this far is one for the history books.
the next time you go to the beach look out into the ocean. who's war ship will you see? chinese, russian or maybe iranian.

in reply to craig geary.

where did you get your info about millions of vietnamese being slaughtered?

Once upon a time there was a guy named MacArthur who wanted to do the same thing - nearly got us into WWIII, with the Chinese. Yes, we would have won, but at what cost or benefit?

Today's situation is similar - do we really need another mess in the Middle-East, blindly supporting Israel while opposing small nations that pose us no real threat, while demonstrating obvious policy inconsistencies vs. our positions on Israel, India, and possibly others? So far, the 'benefits' of doing such include 9/11, two oil embargoes, billions wasted in aid (bribes), trillions wasted in a bloated military and needless wars.

President Obama has allowed himself to be pushed around too many times already by the military - eg. Generals McChrystal and Petraeus, along with Secretary Gates and innumerable Congressional chicken hawks. If Admiral Fox wants more freedom, Obama should give him a one-man canoe and set him free.

War is much too serious to be left to the generals, or in this case an admiral.
Their institutional bias is more war, more spending, more promotions. I witnessed part of the slaughter of literally millions of Vietnamese. If it was up to the generals we'd still be there.

The next red herring is " growing Chinese threat". They have no reason to attempt to harm us, they want to sell us boatloads of stuff AND collect what we owe.

The usual republican chickenhawks, in this case draft dodging Gingrich and Romney, VietNam avoiders both, want war with Iran and to play up the aforementioned "Chinese threat."

The congressional-military-industrial complex is ever ravenous.

Don't get fooled again. Next arm chair warrior you hear spouting Fox, ask that sunshine patriot if he plans to send his son.

Any fool that thinks Iran is going to be easy should enlist in the israeli defense force and see for themselves.

Our navy consumes the same amount of energy as Sweden, the whole country. Why? To patrol the world for Big Oil. The sooner we cut back, conserve, increase efficiency, use natural gas the less need to garrison the 130 bases we have overseas.
They (Mead and Murray) fail to explain how educated and skilled workers become part of the underclass system once they are over 50.

Unemployment and underemployment unravel the economic, social and family fabrics. It is facile not to address these problems directly and this article suggests that neither Murray ("Let them attend church, attend school and eat cake,") nor Mead ("It's raining soup,") does so.

As well, neither theory accounts for the many unemployed and underemployed Americans who are highly educated and well-inculcated in upper echelon mores. Job creation and economic growth are needed urgently, and their lack fuels the growth of the American underclass.

You are quite right in saying that the GOP seems to see a tax cut as a cure for all of our economic and social ills. I fear that some time soon they will proclaim it to be a cure for the common cold and male pattern baldness.

I agreed, this whole problem comes to one point. Education  and commonsense. Our capitalist society careless about educate our people,the only objective is PROFIT. More buyers uneducated,more lies can  be accomplish. Our high-school kids have no idea with position Hillary Clinton or Nancy Pelosi, or who is our treasure secretary, and if you ask any other person if they vote, usually the answer is : For What ? For decades, the capitalism (Corporate America), dictates our lives from what we buy, what to believe, and who is the candidate is going to serve them and continue deregulation,  privitize andcontinue to keep a good percentage of americans ignorants.

"For decades the G.O.P. has won elections by appealing to social and racial divisions, only to turn after each victory to deregulation and tax cuts for the wealthy" : was there ever a more succinct description of how we got here from there?

I'd love for someone to put together a compilation of the number of times Republicans shouted "Tax Cut" as a solution to whatever problem was mentioned: crime, pollution, education, health care, global warming (if it existed, which it doesn't); evolution (if it existed), ad nauseam....

What I'd like to know, is how come a category of individuals can be forced to have insurance out of pocket, because of the mandate targeting them? This applies if they are not covered by their employer and report an income that is above the poverty line.

But then, Institutes of organized religion don't have to 'volunteer' covering a certain health element, because of their moral position????

Repeal the forced mandate portion of ObamaCare.

These moral issues get bottled up. Organized religion has always banked on the incentive to subordinate females. It's as if women's sexuality has to be punished with such a sexist lesson. Force and violence are the only method preached by our religious leaders to prevent women from fulfilling their potential as citizens, in society.

Shame is not enough to combat those who use the issue to suppress women and girls.

Obama needs to remind himself that American Catholic bishops and cardinals are appointed by the Pope and beholden to him alone. Thus they speak for only the Pope, not their American parishioners, despite their claims to the contrary. Every Catholic bishop in this country should be regarded by the American government as equivalent to the local consul general of a foreign state, entitled to express the opinion of that state, in this case the Vatican, but without  a voice of any kind in American governmental issues.

Amen. Blessed are the tweakers; and those willing to compromise to accomplish their aims while moving the country back from a holy war.

Among other reasons for actively eschewing holy wars, the fact that they're becoming boring stands out. What cannot be resolved eventually becomes boring. You can tell the Church all you want about the need for equality in health care, and the cost-benefit aspects of contraception over abortion; but you're not going to make much of a dent short of laws that compel despite vocal resistance. You can tell secularists all you want about the evil of a tyranny that compels the religious to do things that the secularists regard as right but that the religion teaches is wrong, particularly in a country where we constitutionally seek to separate these worlds into what is rendered Caesar and what is rendered God; but you're not going to make much of a dent in the conviction that secular relativism is the only legitimate religion.

Given (if you're prepared to give it) that one side is not going to convince the other, and that we're still about 50-50 on these issues, "tweaking" or compromise, reasonable accommodation, is the only path to moving forward as a people. Unless, of course, what is preferable is for both sides to be braying at the moon forever, proud in their purist wrath, while the whole world passes us by and we become Rome, circa 476 CE.

Responding to Muñoz’s assertion that “most women, including 98 percent of Catholic women, have used contraception,” the Bishops stated:

"This is irrelevant, and it is presented in a misleading way. If a survey found that 98% of people had lied, cheated on their taxes, or had sex outside of marriage, would the government claim it can force everyone to do so? But this claim also mangles the data to create a false impression. The study actually says this is true of 98% of “sexually experienced” women. The more relevant statistic is that the drugs and devices subject to this mandate (sterilization, hormonal prescription contraceptives and IUDs) are used by 69% of those women who are “sexually active” and “do not want to become pregnant.”

The linking of the Catholic Church and the Evangelicals in the person of Santorum is a phenomenon worth noting. The hatred of Obama is so virulent it has accomplished this near impossible alliance.

Add to that the need of an infallible but humiliated Church -- ridiculed for its scandals and for the defections from doctrine by so many of its flock -- and you have a recipe for aggression.

The notion Santorum advocates that the Founders, and Jefferson in particular, would have supported Catholicism's dictating law to the U.S. government -- a Church that claims absolute authority on public matters in this world from a world beyond -- is ludicrous.

Santorum's Medievalism is correct as a description of his Church; our Founders rejected that. The Texas Evangelical pastors laying on of hands upon Santorum and blessing his campaign is something new in our politics. JFK rejected the authority of his Church in the public sphere; it seems among many that is no longer necessary.

Rick Santorum took the occasion of the latest skirmish in the Culture Wars to strike a blow against the French Revolution. Apparently Liberte, Egalite are all right with Rick but Robespierre , apparently channeling Rick Perry, didn't attach the proper third leg of the modernist stool. It's paternite rather than fraternite that will save the family of man; the affinity of the latter with solidarity, being the steel edge of the guilotine.

Rick went on to remind us of the epoch journey of his cold mining (and pro-communist) grandfather, who fled Mussolini in search of La Liberte. Ironically the philosophical basis of Italian fascism was its violent opposition to the French Revolution.

So much for Homeschooling.

We understand the issues. Catholic Church was shown to be flaming hypocrits again, already covering birth control for years.
Your church repeatedly violates the provisions where tax exempt institutions foreswear politics, by self-important bishops telling congregations how to vote. Your church castigates Democratic Catholic candidates for their legislative decisions, but they let Gringrich into their enclave recently with the most disgusting marriage record of any candidate in politics on either side. The government isn't destroying your religion, it is falling apart from the inside due to pediphillia, sex discrimination, encouraging hatred against gays, hypocrisy, and other evil forces. The Catholic church discriminates against women on every single issue, and makes sure it stays that way by refusing women entrance into any leadership position. Would it be okay to have the same prohibition against people of color as priests in the year 2012?
We will all pay for the birth control pills gladly in healthcare premiums or taxes, in order to be exempt from the dictates of a small, white, male insular enclave who wants to force issues down eveyone else's throat in the name of religious superiority.
Religious freedom also includes freedom from religion you find insincere and corrupt.

Yes, an anti-Roman-Catholic-Church-as-an institution-in-America viewpoint, brought about by the Bishops' own bias against women having control over their own bodies, plus the institution's by now well-documented willingness to protect child rapists.

As an institution, the church has a very unsavory history, in favor of religious liberty only when it has been prevented from having an effective monopoly, brought about by persecuting non Catholics. The Bishops are now interested in their own freedom of conscience but continue to do all in their power to impose their views on everyone else, in the matter of birth control, abortion and gay rights. Do they stand up as strongly for the poor, for opposing war and similar matters where even the Pope has taken strong stands? In general, no.

The time has come for good people to consider a boycott of all universities, hospitals and schools that are subservient to those Bishops.

Religious liberty for individuals to practice may be protected by the First Amendment, but the absurd dogma and decrees  incompatible with the mores, norms and standards of the 21st century that effect health, well being, sexual, reproductive lives and what folks need and can afford is not. The 14th Amendment of equal protection and general  welfare for all  takes precedence over the Catholic State, within a State, enjoying all the diplomatic privileges and accepting none of the responsibilities. With over dollar trillion in investment, paying no taxes. The hierarchy living in a Palace, high on the hog at the expense of the poor, ignorant and mostly illiterate folk, forced into servitude.

As a Cafeteria Catholic (sing in the choir even) I dispute those who believe the Church is being ill treated. Not so. The Church is playing a game with us. Unlike with Bible colleges and other fringe institutions, the Church established institutions that are fully capable of playing in the mainstream. As a result, the Church receives tax payer money in the form of govt supported student loans, Pell grants, Medicare and Medicaid payments, and even research grants.

Yet when in this issue, where most women behave as if Birth Control were the norm, the Church raises itself up and says we have a different point of view. Ok, if you want it that way, you ought to remove yourself from the game and become just a church - and one in steep decline.

So along with getting your way on Birth Control, time to start refusing all government money. in a few years, no one will remember why anyone cared what a few old men believed on any issue.

Lets just outsource the government to WalMart. Put a chapel in each megabox, next to the dentist, insurance agent and check cashing desk, right next to the tires and automotive section (which also houses the recently aquired pet store chain), down the aisle from the sporting goods, but near the bathrooms, and of course the pharmacy, please. Folks will have much less animus to "Wallycare" than they apparently do to Obamacare, to hear the republicans tell it, and if it includes auto, home and dental, everyone wins! Did I mention travel insurance for Seamus?
I could walk in, buy Viagra, ammo and absolution, new tires, a root canal, cash my welfare check, collect my food stamps, drop off my tithe, and still go thru the express check-out/TSA exam station. . The greeters in the blue vests will be replaced by burly ex-football player types wearing dark blue blazers, dark wrap around sun glasses and sport those curley wired earbuds.
The former government buildings along Pennsylvania Ave., and elsewhere, can be privatized at a profit, and become call centers, prisons and hospitals. Our government will become adept at slashing prices, bullying suppliers to cut costs, and targeted advertising. With the addition of a giant dollar sign, the new national monumet at the reflecting pool will be the Wally monument.
All this will serve to lessen the influence of the church, and the extremists, and remake America as the home of the brave and the land of the grand bargain.

Abortion shouldn't be held hostage by religion or government.  Abortion is very serious personal life choice.  Government should stay out of it and not provide any funding to make it political.  Religious groups should also stay out of it because their Lord was born out of wedlock by unwanted pregnancy without abortion available.

Great column as usual.  Hard to believe anyone other than Karl Rove, the Republican presidential candidates and a few actual human beings would not be pleased by this resolution.  Perhaps the problems is that people watch too much TV and read too many blogs.  Every idiot in the world is now able to put his lunatic thoughts out there for all to read, and the intense media hyper-coverage tends to focus on the most extreme positions.

"It's not really about birth control" today, but it was all about birth control just 48 hours ago. Must of read 30 posts applauding the President's thesis explaining how birth control was health care, how this was much ado about nothing given 98 percent of catholic women were using birth control anyway, how disgustingly hipocritical it was for anyone to dare question the legality or morality of the mandate, especially if they did so from a perspective of faith.

Like the President's flip-flop on his stead-fast position, the enlightened views of Ms. Collins, and apparently the resolve of 98 percent of those who dilligently try to convince themselves and others that government run health care is the best thing since sliced bread, this is/was a colosal and expected cave on the issue.

Yep, a fine display of Presidential gravitas and leadership alright. Simply retreat behind the lines when faced with adversity and always fall back to the safety of having those 50 percent who actually pay taxes do your dirty work.

Bravo!

Herr Freud would have a field day with this. It's not about contraception. It's about the Catholic hierarchy's conflicted view of sexuality, and bishops' anguish over their parishioner's being sexual and enjoying it outside of procreation. I'm guessing that if the church had a married clergy this issue would be turned on its head. I saw no protestant clergy demanding redress from the White House for their Methodist, or Lutheran, or Baptist hospitals. Separation of church and state--what a wonderful concept.

What would be incredibly refreshing, at this point, would be to see the Bishops and other members of the Catholic "establishment" publicly recognize the fact that the President gave them what they wanted.  And, while they're at it, perhaps they could state that Universal Health Care is fully in keeping with their traditions, as is winding down wars, etc., etc.  I know that the Church can't support gay rights, or "choice", but what I don't understand is why they're willing to compromise on things like "war" and the "death penalty" when the right is in power.  Why is it a zero-sum game when a so-called liberal is in office, but not when a conservative is?  Is it me, or does the Church appear to be situationally "moral"?

Whose religious liberty was being compromised? Nobody was being forced to do anything against their will. I worked in two Catholic hospitals. Most of the employees were not Catholic. Most of the Catholics practiced birth control. You want condums out of all Catholic affiliated organizations? OK, keep all and any rerferences to God, including creationism, out of public schools.

A president Santorum would commission 'sex police' to assure that no man on man, woman on woman or his favorite man on dog shenanigans  are taking place.  Man/woman sexual encounters would be for married people whose only purpose is procreation.  It's going to have to be a pretty large police force.

To call it a moral opposition on the part of the catholic bishops would be disingenuous.  They're moral opposition to birth control extends to the use of condoms in countries with a high prevalence of AIDS infection.  They don't mind if people are spreading a deadly virus so long as you're only copulating with the intent of procreating.  It's as hypocritical as Republican right-to-lifers demanding that a fertilized egg be defined as a wholly separate life because, life is sacred, while they support violent acts against other nations.
